Claim: India has decided to extend its financial year to July 1 due to the current COVID-19 outbreak.
Explaination: The Income Tax department tweeted that the financial year has not been extended and that this gazette was for the collection of stamp duty on security market instruments through stock exchanges and clearing corporations.
Label: False
html:
Claim: India has decided to extend its financial year to July 1 due to the current COVID-19 outbreak.

Explanation:The Income Tax department tweeted that the financial year has not been extended and that this gazette was for the collection of stamp duty on security market instruments through stock exchanges and clearing corporations.

https://www.boomlive.in/fake-news/indias-financial-year-has-not-been-extended-to-july-1-7466

Claim: Says imposters in hazmat suits are going door to door in Stockton, California, saying they are checking residents for fever or COVID-19, but they “will enter your home and physically attempt robbery.”
Explaination: Posts around the nation warn people not to open their doors to imposters who say they are doing coronavirus testing but actually want to rob the residents. Like other such claims, this one about an alleged scam in Stockton, Calif., is false, according to police.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Says imposters in hazmat suits are going door to door in Stockton, California, saying they are checking residents for fever or COVID-19, but they “will enter your home and physically attempt robbery.”

Explanation:Posts around the nation warn people not to open their doors to imposters who say they are doing coronavirus testing but actually want to rob the residents. Like other such claims, this one about an alleged scam in Stockton, Calif., is false, according to police.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/mar/30/facebook-posts/another-false-claim-robbers-posing-covid-19-tester/

Claim: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited a mosque amid the coronavirus outbreak and asked the people of the Muslim community to pray about present crisis.
Explaination: Chinese President Xi Jinping’s visit to the mosque is not related to coronavirus as the viral video is almost-four-year-old.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited a mosque amid the coronavirus outbreak and asked the people of the Muslim community to pray about present crisis.

Explanation:Chinese President Xi Jinping’s visit to the mosque is not related to coronavirus as the viral video is almost-four-year-old.

http://newsmobile.in/articles/2020/02/07/chinese-prez-visited-mosque-amid-coronavirus-outbreak-heres-the-truth-behind-the-viral-video/

Claim: Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced a 14-hour curfew as the virus lives for 12 hours on surfaces.
Explaination: Research studies show that The study found the new coronavirus can live in the air for several hours and on some surfaces for as long as 2 -3 days. These studies are not peer reviewed.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced a 14-hour curfew as the virus lives for 12 hours on surfaces.

Explanation:Research studies show that The study found the new coronavirus can live in the air for several hours and on some surfaces for as long as 2 -3 days. These studies are not peer reviewed.

https://www.boomlive.in/fact-file/message-claiming-coronavirus-lives-on-a-surface-for-12-hours-is-mis

Claim: This photo shows the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The photo is a magnified photo of a weevil.
Label: False
html:
Claim: This photo shows the novel coronavirus.

Explanation:The photo is a magnified photo of a weevil.

https://factcheck.afp.com/no-magnified-photo-weevil

Claim: OMS staff member is spreading coronavirus on purpose.
Explaination: The man is an astrophysicist, and he is touching this lady because she is his girlfriend, and she is sick.
Label: False
html:
Claim: OMS staff member is spreading coronavirus on purpose.

Explanation:The man is an astrophysicist, and he is touching this lady because she is his girlfriend, and she is sick.

https://observers.france24.com/fr/20200312-coronavirus-attention-ces-intox-alimentent-theories-complot

Claim: Whether coronavirus began with man having sex with a bat.
Explaination: This came from a clear satire website as fake.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Whether coronavirus began with man having sex with a bat.

Explanation:This came from a clear satire website as fake.

https://leadstories.com/hoax-alert/2020/03/Fact-Check-Coronavirus-'Patient-Zero'-Is-NOT-A-Man-Who-Had-Sex-With-A-Bat.html

Claim: Green chiratta can prevent COVID-19.
Explaination: No scientific evidence for that.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Green chiratta can prevent COVID-19.

Explanation:No scientific evidence for that.

https://factcheck.afp.com/thai-health-experts-say-there-no-evidence-green-chiretta-herb-can-prevent-novel-coronavirus

Claim: A video has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim that it shows a drone launching fireworks at people who breached a curfew in Malaysia during a nationwide coronavirus lockdown.
Explaination: The claim is false; the video's audio has been manipulated to include a man speaking in Malaysian; the original clip actually shows a prank that was staged by a Brazilian influencer in Brazil in July 2019.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A video has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim that it shows a drone launching fireworks at people who breached a curfew in Malaysia during a nationwide coronavirus lockdown.

Explanation:The claim is false; the video's audio has been manipulated to include a man speaking in Malaysian; the original clip actually shows a prank that was staged by a Brazilian influencer in Brazil in July 2019.

https://factcheck.afp.com/video-has-circulated-online-about-prank-staged-brazil-2019

Claim: The Taiwanese flag is printed on masks to prevent the Chinese from buying them.
Explaination: Production of the mask with the national flag started at the latest in 2019. There is no relationship with this coronavirus. Posts posted as "jokes" on Taiwanese Internet bulletin boards have spread.
Label: False
html:
Claim: The Taiwanese flag is printed on masks to prevent the Chinese from buying them.

Explanation:Production of the mask with the national flag started at the latest in 2019. There is no relationship with this coronavirus. Posts posted as "jokes" on Taiwanese Internet bulletin boards have spread.

https://www.buzzfeed.com/jp/kotahatachi/unknown-cause-china-4

Claim: Second-hand clothes and blankets sold cheaply in African markets are infected with coronavirus.
Explaination: The photo is at least ten years old. China imports mostly new clothes to Africa, but WHO, Harvard Medical School and other experts advise it is safe to receive goods from COVID-19 affected areas.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Second-hand clothes and blankets sold cheaply in African markets are infected with coronavirus.

Explanation:The photo is at least ten years old. China imports mostly new clothes to Africa, but WHO, Harvard Medical School and other experts advise it is safe to receive goods from COVID-19 affected areas.

https://africacheck.org/fbcheck/no-photo-not-of-covid-19-infected-clothes-blankets-and-you-wont-get-the-virus-from-imported-goods/

Claim: The health service in Ireland is asking people to stockpile food.
Explaination: The claim was untrue. The health service is not urging people to stockpile food - in fact, the opposite is true - and the supply chains in Ireland remain robust
Label: False
html:
Claim: The health service in Ireland is asking people to stockpile food.

Explanation:The claim was untrue. The health service is not urging people to stockpile food - in fact, the opposite is true - and the supply chains in Ireland remain robust

https://jrnl.ie/5045982

Claim: Garlic water can cure novel coronavirus.
Explaination: Garlic is a healthy food that may have some antimicrobial properties. However, there is no evidence from the current outbreak that eating garlic has protected people from the new coronavirus.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Garlic water can cure novel coronavirus.

Explanation:Garlic is a healthy food that may have some antimicrobial properties. However, there is no evidence from the current outbreak that eating garlic has protected people from the new coronavirus.

https://www.vishvasnews.com/english/health/fact-check-post-claiming-garlic-water-can-cure-novel-coronavirus-is-fake/

Claim: Not a single Muslim died of coronavirus in China.
Explaination: There is no such claim made by China so far that not a single Muslim has died of coronavirus. China has not released any list of people who have died in coronavirus.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Not a single Muslim died of coronavirus in China.

Explanation:There is no such claim made by China so far that not a single Muslim has died of coronavirus. China has not released any list of people who have died in coronavirus.

https://aajtak.intoday.in/story/fact-check-due-to-corona-virus-not-killed-single-muslim-in-china-viral-post-1-1173328.html

Claim: A claim has been shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter in Sri Lanka that the ruler of Sharjah, one of the seven emirates of the United Arab Emirates (UAE), banned burials of people who died after contracting the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false; the UAE Embassy in Sri Lanka refuted the claim and said Sharjah ruler's Sultan bin Muhammad Al-Qasimi only said that novel coronavirus victims should not be buried in one specific location in Sharjah.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A claim has been shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter in Sri Lanka that the ruler of Sharjah, one of the seven emirates of the United Arab Emirates (UAE), banned burials of people who died after contracting the novel coronavirus.

Explanation:The claim is false; the UAE Embassy in Sri Lanka refuted the claim and said Sharjah ruler's Sultan bin Muhammad Al-Qasimi only said that novel coronavirus victims should not be buried in one specific location in Sharjah.

https://factcheck.afp.com/sharjah-ruler-sultan-bin-muhammad-al-qasimi-did-not-ban-burial-covid-19-victims-april-2020

Claim: Facebook posts shared thousands of times recommend various practices to prevent COVID-19, including gargling salt water, drinking tea and avoiding ice cream.
Explaination: Health experts told AFP there is no evidence to support these claims and say washing your hands regularly is the best way to stay healthy.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Facebook posts shared thousands of times recommend various practices to prevent COVID-19, including gargling salt water, drinking tea and avoiding ice cream.

Explanation:Health experts told AFP there is no evidence to support these claims and say washing your hands regularly is the best way to stay healthy.

https://factcheck.afp.com/health-authorities-warn-false-covid-19-prevention-tips-online

Claim: Coronavirus cases reported in Rome, Georgia.
Explaination: The medical facility issued a statement saying there was not a confirmed case.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Coronavirus cases reported in Rome, Georgia.

Explanation:The medical facility issued a statement saying there was not a confirmed case.

https://hoax-alert.leadstories.com/3471649-fake-news-no-coronavirus-cases-reported-in-rome-georgia.html

Claim: A lengthy post purportedly contains advice on how to prevent infection from the novel coronavirus. The post claims the advice was issued by a UK hospital to its medical staff.
Explaination: The claim is false; the hospital named in the misleading Facebook posts denied issuing the guidelines; the posts also contained several false claims previously debunked by AFP Fact Check.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A lengthy post purportedly contains advice on how to prevent infection from the novel coronavirus. The post claims the advice was issued by a UK hospital to its medical staff.

Explanation:The claim is false; the hospital named in the misleading Facebook posts denied issuing the guidelines; the posts also contained several false claims previously debunked by AFP Fact Check.

https://factcheck.afp.com/hoax-circulates-uk-hospital-has-issued-special-advice-staff-prevent-covid-19-infection

Claim: Health Ministry in Ecuador confirms three new cases of coronavirus.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False
html:
Claim: Health Ministry in Ecuador confirms three new cases of coronavirus.

Explanation:Please click the link to read the full article

http://www.ecuadorchequea.com/coronavirus-ecuador-guayaquil-salud-informacion/?fbclid=IwAR3PtQ-aae42TDcU0pxjgjxbG_u2PeV2Mk8kgpLRQ0JU_Xr7npmpjrF_-ZQ

Claim: A “Wuhan super virus” was created in a Chinese biosecurity lab and has infected more than 100,000 people in Wuhan.
Explaination: There is no evidence that the 2019 Novel coronavirus came from a Chinese laboratory. The WHO says the virus most likely originated in an animal. The number of cases of infection with the coronavirus in Wuhan has not reached 100,000 as claimed in the video.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A “Wuhan super virus” was created in a Chinese biosecurity lab and has infected more than 100,000 people in Wuhan.

Explanation:There is no evidence that the 2019 Novel coronavirus came from a Chinese laboratory. The WHO says the virus most likely originated in an animal. The number of cases of infection with the coronavirus in Wuhan has not reached 100,000 as claimed in the video.

https://factcheck.aap.com.au/social-media-claims/no-evidence-2019-coronavirus-came-from-a-chinese-lab

Claim: President Trump refers to the coronavirus as a hoax in an audio clip.
Explaination: Audio and video clips were purposely edited.
Label: False
html:
Claim: President Trump refers to the coronavirus as a hoax in an audio clip.

Explanation:Audio and video clips were purposely edited.

https://leadstories.com/hoax-alert/2020/04/fact-check-president-trump-did-not-refer-to-coronavirus-as-a-hoax.html

Claim: Food and locations are contaminated in Australia.
Explaination: Authorities denied those claims.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Food and locations are contaminated in Australia.

Explanation:Authorities denied those claims.

Explanation:This is a generalization and hasn't happened everywhere.

Claim: An audio clip claiming to be of renowned heart surgeon Dr Devi Shetty is going viral on Facebook, Twitter, and WhatsApp.
Explaination: The viral clip has been falsely attributed to Dr Devi Shetty.
Label: Mostly false
html:

Explanation:The viral clip has been falsely attributed to Dr Devi Shetty.
